frontmatter.title: Note on WHIR: Reed-Solomon Proximity Testing with Super-Fast Verification

children.value: This article mainly introduces the WHIR (Weights Help Improving Rate) protocol [ACFY24b]. Like the FRI [BBHR18], STIR [ACFY24a], and BaseFold [ZCF24] protocols, WHIR is also an IOPP protocol, but it has a smaller query complexity and a faster verification time. The paper [ACFY24b] mentions that WHIR’s verifier typically runs in hundreds of microseconds (1 microsecond =
seconds), while other protocols’ verifiers take a few milliseconds (1 millisecond =
seconds). Additionally, WHIR is an IOPP protocol for

(CRS), which allows WHIR to support queries for both multivariate linear polynomials and univariate polynomials, which is why WHIR can be compared simultaneously with BaseFold, FRI, and STIR [ACFY24b]. Overall, WHIR combines the ideas of BaseFold and STIR, enabling the WHIR protocol to support multivariate linear polynomials without sacrificing Prover efficiency and argument size, while also having a smaller query complexity.
From Univariate Polynomials to Multivariate Linear Polynomials

children.label: From Univariate Polynomials to Multivariate Linear Polynomials

children.value: For univariate polynomials in the RS code

children.value: , it’s similar, they can be viewed from the perspective of multivariate linear polynomials, i.e.,

children.html: RS[F,L,d]:={f:L→F:∃g^∈F<2m[X] s.t. ∀x∈L,f(x)=g^(x)}={f:L→F:∃f^∈F<2[X1,…,Xm] s.t. ∀x∈L,f(x)=f^(x20,x21,…,x2m−1)}\begin{aligned} \mathrm{RS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}, d] & := \{f: \mathcal{L} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}: \exists \hat{g} \in \mathbb{F}^{< 2^m}[X] \text{ s.t. } \forall x \in \mathcal{L}, f(x) = \hat{g}(x)\} \\ & = \{f: \mathcal{L} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}: \exists \hat{f} \in \mathbb{F}^{< 2}[X_1, \ldots, X_m] \text{ s.t. } \forall x \in \mathcal{L}, f(x) = \hat{f}(x^{2^0}, x^{2^1},\ldots, x^{2^{m-1}})\} \end{aligned}RS[F,L,d]​:={f:L→F:∃g^​∈F<2m[X] s.t. ∀x∈L,f(x)=g^​(x)}={f:L→F:∃f^​∈F<2[X1​,…,Xm​] s.t. ∀x∈L,f(x)=f^​(x20,x21,…,x2m−1)}​
g^(x)\hat{g}(x)g^​(x)
f^(X1,…,Xm)\hat{f}(X_1, \ldots, X_m)f^​(X1​,…,Xm​)

Furthermore, consistent with the FRI protocol, folding a univariate polynomial with a random number

children.html: α1\alpha_1α1​

children.value: can be equivalently viewed as substituting

children.html: α1\alpha_1α1​

children.value: for one of the variables in the multivariate linear polynomial.

children.html: f(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+a3x3+a4x4+a5x5+a6x6+a7x7f(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + a_3 x^3 + a_4 x^4 + a_5 x^5 + a_6 x^6 + a_7 x^7f(x)=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+a4​x4+a5​x5+a6​x6+a7​x7
α1\alpha_1α1​

f(x)=a0+a2x2+a4x4+a6x6+x(a1+a3x2+a5x4+a7x6):=f1(x2)+xf2(x2)\begin{aligned} f(x) & = a_0 + a_2 x^2 + a_4 x^4 + a_6 x^6 + x (a_1 + a_3 x^2 + a_5 x^4 + a_7 x^6) \\ & := f_1(x^2) + x f_2(x^2) \end{aligned}f(x)​=a0​+a2​x2+a4​x4+a6​x6+x(a1​+a3​x2+a5​x4+a7​x6):=f1​(x2)+xf2​(x2)​

f(1)(x)=f1(x)+α1f2(x)=a0+a2x+a4x2+a6x3+α1(a1+a3x+a5x2+a7x3)=a0+a2X1+a4X2+a6X1X2+α1(a1+a3X1+a5X2+a7X1X2)\begin{aligned} f^{(1)}(x) & = f_1(x) + \alpha_1 f_2(x) \\ & = a_0 + a_2 x + a_4 x^2 + a_6 x^3 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 x + a_5 x^2 + a_7 x^3) \\ & = a_0 + a_2 X_1 + a_4 X_2 + a_6 X_1X_2 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 X_1 + a_5 X_2 + a_7 X_1X_2) \end{aligned}f(1)(x)​=f1​(x)+α1​f2​(x)=a0​+a2​x+a4​x2+a6​x3+α1​(a1​+a3​x+a5​x2+a7​x3)=a0​+a2​X1​+a4​X2​+a6​X1​X2​+α1​(a1​+a3​X1​+a5​X2​+a7​X1​X2​)​

children.value: This is equivalent to directly substituting values and replacing variables in the original multivariate polynomial

children.html: f^(X1,X2,X3)\hat{f}(X_1,X_2,X_3)f^​(X1​,X2​,X3​)
X1X_1X1​
α1\alpha_1α1​

f^(α1,X2,X3)=a0+a1⋅α1+a2X2+a3⋅α1X2+a4X3+a5⋅α1X2+a6X2X3+a7⋅α1X2X3=a0+a2X2+a4X3+a6X2X3+α1(a1+a3X2+a5X2+a7X2X3)\begin{aligned} \hat{f}(\alpha_1,X_2,X_3) & = a_0 + a_1 \cdot \alpha_1 + a_2 X_2 + a_3 \cdot \alpha_1 X_2 + a_4 X_3 + a_5 \cdot \alpha_1 X_2 + a_6 X_2 X_3 + a_7 \cdot \alpha_1 X_2 X_3 \\ & = a_0 + a_2 X_2 + a_4 X_3 + a_6 X_2 X_3 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 X_2 + a_5 X_2 + a_7 X_2 X_3) \end{aligned}f^​(α1​,X2​,X3​)​=a0​+a1​⋅α1​+a2​X2​+a3​⋅α1​X2​+a4​X3​+a5​⋅α1​X2​+a6​X2​X3​+a7​⋅α1​X2​X3​=a0​+a2​X2​+a4​X3​+a6​X2​X3​+α1​(a1​+a3​X2​+a5​X2​+a7​X2​X3​)​
X1=X2X_1 = X_2X1​=X2​
X2=X3X_2 = X_3X2​=X3​

children.value: , we get the folded polynomial as

children.html: f^(1)(X1,X2)=a0+a2X1+a4X2+a6X1X2+α1(a1+a3X1+a5X2+a7X1X2)=f(1)(x)\begin{aligned} \hat{f}^{(1)}(X_1, X_2) & = a_0 + a_2 X_1 + a_4 X_2 + a_6 X_1 X_2 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 X_1 + a_5 X_2 + a_7 X_1 X_2) \\ & = f^{(1)}(x) \end{aligned}f^​(1)(X1​,X2​)​=a0​+a2​X1​+a4​X2​+a6​X1​X2​+α1​(a1​+a3​X1​+a5​X2​+a7​X1​X2​)=f(1)(x)​

children.value: We can see that the polynomials obtained by the two folding methods are equivalent, except that

children.html: f(1)(x)f^{(1)}(x)f(1)(x)

children.value: is in the form of a univariate polynomial, while

children.html: f^(1)(X1,X2)\hat{f}^{(1)}(X_1, X_2)f^​(1)(X1​,X2​)

children.value: is in the form of a multivariate linear polynomial.
If we want to perform a 4-fold on the original polynomial

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: , from the perspective of univariate polynomials, we can perform a 2-fold on the polynomial

children.html: f(1)(x)f^{(1)}(x)f(1)(x)

f(1)(x)=a0+a2x+a4x2+a6x3+α1(a1+a3x+a5x2+a7x3)=(a0+α1a1)+(a2+α1a3)⋅x+(a4+α1a5)⋅x2+(a6+α1a7)⋅x3=((a0+α1a1)+(a4+α1a5)⋅x2)+x⋅((a2+α1a3)+(a6+α1a7)⋅x2):=f1(1)(x2)+xf2(1)(x2)\begin{aligned} f^{(1)}(x) & = a_0 + a_2 x + a_4 x^2 + a_6 x^3 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 x + a_5 x^2 + a_7 x^3) \\ & = (a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) \cdot x + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) \cdot x^2 + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) \cdot x^3 \\ & = ((a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) \cdot x^2) + x \cdot ((a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) \cdot x^2) \\ & := f_1^{(1)}(x^2) + x f_2^{(1)}(x^2) \end{aligned}f(1)(x)​=a0​+a2​x+a4​x2+a6​x3+α1​(a1​+a3​x+a5​x2+a7​x3)=(a0​+α1​a1​)+(a2​+α1​a3​)⋅x+(a4​+α1​a5​)⋅x2+(a6​+α1​a7​)⋅x3=((a0​+α1​a1​)+(a4​+α1​a5​)⋅x2)+x⋅((a2​+α1​a3​)+(a6​+α1​a7​)⋅x2):=f1(1)​(x2)+xf2(1)​(x2)​
α2\alpha_2α2​

children.value: , we get the folded polynomial as

children.html: f(2)(x)=f1(1)(x)+α2f2(1)(x)=((a0+α1a1)+(a4+α1a5)x)+α2((a2+α1a3)+(a6+α1a7)x)=((a0+α1a1)+(a4+α1a5)X1)+α2((a2+α1a3)+(a6+α1a7)X1)\begin{aligned} f^{(2)}(x) & = f_1^{(1)}(x) + \alpha_2 f_2^{(1)}(x) \\ & = ((a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) x) + \alpha_2 ((a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) x) \\ & = ((a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) X_1) + \alpha_2 ((a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) X_1) \end{aligned}f(2)(x)​=f1(1)​(x)+α2​f2(1)​(x)=((a0​+α1​a1​)+(a4​+α1​a5​)x)+α2​((a2​+α1​a3​)+(a6​+α1​a7​)x)=((a0​+α1​a1​)+(a4​+α1​a5​)X1​)+α2​((a2​+α1​a3​)+(a6​+α1​a7​)X1​)​

children.value: From the perspective of multivariate linear polynomials, we can perform a 2-fold on the multivariate linear polynomial

children.html: f^(1)(X1,X2)\hat{f}^{(1)}(X_1, X_2)f^​(1)(X1​,X2​)
X1X_1X1​
α2\alpha_2α2​

f^(1)(α2,X2)=a0+a2α2+a4X2+a6α2X2+α1(a1+a3α2+a5X2+a7α2X2)=((a0+α1a1)+(a4+α1a5)X2)+α2((a2+α1a3)+(a6+α1a7)X2)\begin{aligned} \hat{f}^{(1)}(\alpha_2, X_2) & = a_0 + a_2 \alpha_2 + a_4 X_2 + a_6 \alpha_2 X_2 + \alpha_1 (a_1 + a_3 \alpha_2 + a_5 X_2 + a_7 \alpha_2 X_2) \\ & = ((a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) X_2) + \alpha_2 ((a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) X_2) \end{aligned}f^​(1)(α2​,X2​)​=a0​+a2​α2​+a4​X2​+a6​α2​X2​+α1​(a1​+a3​α2​+a5​X2​+a7​α2​X2​)=((a0​+α1​a1​)+(a4​+α1​a5​)X2​)+α2​((a2​+α1​a3​)+(a6​+α1​a7​)X2​)​
X1=X2X_1 = X_2X1​=X2​

children.value: , we get the folded polynomial as

children.html: f^(2)(X1)=((a0+α1a1)+(a4+α1a5)X1)+α2((a2+α1a3)+(a6+α1a7)X1)\hat{f}^{(2)}(X_1) = ((a_0 + \alpha_1 a_1) + (a_4 + \alpha_1 a_5) X_1) + \alpha_2 ((a_2 + \alpha_1 a_3) + (a_6 + \alpha_1 a_7) X_1)f^​(2)(X1​)=((a0​+α1​a1​)+(a4​+α1​a5​)X1​)+α2​((a2​+α1​a3​)+(a6​+α1​a7​)X1​)

children.value: We can find that for multiple folds, folding using univariate polynomials and directly folding using multivariate linear polynomials are equivalent. The process of folding a multivariate linear polynomial with random numbers

children.html: (α1,α2)(\alpha_1, \alpha_2)(α1​,α2​)

children.value: is just the process of direct variable substitution, i.e., we get

children.html: f^(2)(X1)=f^(α1,α2,X1)\hat{f}^{(2)}(X_1) = \hat{f}(\alpha_1, \alpha_2, X_1)f^​(2)(X1​)=f^​(α1​,α2​,X1​)

children.value: Below we introduce the definition of the folding function given in the paper [ACFY24b], which is consistent with the folding method in the FRI protocol.

children.html: f:L→Ff: \mathcal{L} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}f:L→F
α∈F\alpha \in \mathbb{F}α∈F
Fold(f,α):L2→F\mathrm{Fold}(f, \alpha): \mathcal{L}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{F}Fold(f,α):L2→F

∀x∈L2,  Fold(f,α)(x2)=f(x)+f(−x)2+α⋅f(x)−f(−x)2⋅x\forall x \in \mathcal{L}^2, \; \mathrm{Fold}(f, \alpha)(x^2) = \frac{f(x) + f(-x)}{2} + \alpha \cdot \frac{f(x) - f(-x)}{2 \cdot x}∀x∈L2,Fold(f,α)(x2)=2f(x)+f(−x)​+α⋅2⋅xf(x)−f(−x)​
Fold(f,α)(x2)\mathrm{Fold}(f, \alpha)(x^2)Fold(f,α)(x2)

children.value: The following proposition tells us that folding a Reed-Solomon code on any set of points still results in a Reed-Solomon code. ([ACFY24b])

children.html: f:L→Ff: \mathcal{L} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}f:L→F
α∈Fk\boldsymbol{\alpha} \in \mathbb{F}^kα∈Fk
g:=Fold(f,α)g:= \mathrm{Fold}(f, \boldsymbol{\alpha})g:=Fold(f,α)
f∈RS[F,L,m]f \in \mathrm{RS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}, m]f∈RS[F,L,m]
k≤mk \le mk≤m
g∈RS[F,L(2k),m−k]g \in \mathrm{RS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}^{(2^k)}, m-k]g∈RS[F,L(2k),m−k]
ggg
g^(Xk,…,Xm):=f^(α,Xk,…,Xm)\hat{g}(X_k, \ldots, X_m) := \hat{f}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}, X_k, \ldots, X_m)g^​(Xk​,…,Xm​):=f^​(α,Xk​,…,Xm​)
f^\hat{f}f^​
fff
g^(Xk,…,Xm):=f^(α,Xk,…,Xm)\hat{g}(X_k, \ldots, X_m) := \hat{f}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}, X_k, \ldots, X_m)g^​(Xk​,…,Xm​):=f^​(α,Xk​,…,Xm​)

children.value: given in the proposition is consistent with the folding of the univariate polynomial

children.html: fff

children.value: and the direct folding of the multivariate linear polynomial

children.html: f^\hat{f}f^​

children.value: with random numbers mentioned above. From the perspective of multivariate linear polynomials, it is just direct variable substitution with random numbers

children.html: α\boldsymbol{\alpha}α
f^(α,Xk,…,Xm)\hat{f}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}, X_k, \ldots, X_m)f^​(α,Xk​,…,Xm​)

children.value: Recalling the FRI protocol, it continuously folds the univariate polynomial

children.html: fff
(α1,…,αm)(\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_m)(α1​,…,αm​)

children.value: until finally obtaining a constant polynomial. From the perspective of multivariate linear polynomials, we would eventually get

children.html: f^(α1,…,αm)\hat{f}(\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_m)f^​(α1​,…,αm​)

children.value: as a constant. Connecting to the Sumcheck protocol, the last step also requires obtaining the value of a multivariate polynomial at a certain random point, and the verifier needs to obtain this value for verification. This step is usually implemented using an oracle. Now the FRI protocol can also provide the value of

children.html: f^(α1,…,αm)\hat{f}(\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_m)f^​(α1​,…,αm​)

children.value: at a random point at the end. If the Sumcheck protocol and the FRI protocol choose the same random point

children.html: (α1,…,αm)(\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_m)(α1​,…,αm​)

children.value: , then the FRI protocol can directly provide the value needed for the last step of the Sumcheck protocol when it reaches the end. Combining the FRI protocol and the Sumcheck protocol in this way is the idea of the BaseFold protocol [ZCF24].
Below is the definition of constrained Reed-Solomon codes given in the WHIR paper [ACFY24b]. It is a subset of Reed-Solomon codes, but with an additional constraint similar to Sumcheck.

children.html: F\mathbb{F}F
L⊆F\mathcal{L} \subseteq \mathbb{F}L⊆F
m∈Nm \in \mathbb{N}m∈N
w^∈F[Z,X1,…,Xm]\hat{w} \in \mathbb{F}[Z, X_1, \ldots, X_m]w^∈F[Z,X1​,…,Xm​]
σ∈F\sigma \in \mathbb{F}σ∈F

CRS[F,L,m,w^,σ]:={f∈RS[F,L,m]:∑b∈{0,1}mw^(f^(b),b)=σ}.\mathrm{CRS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}, m, \hat{w}, \sigma] := \left\{ f \in \mathrm{RS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}, m]: \sum_{\mathbf{b} \in \{0,1\}^m} \hat{w}(\hat{f}(\mathbf{b}), \mathbf{b}) = \sigma \right\}.CRS[F,L,m,w^,σ]:=⎩⎨⎧​f∈RS[F,L,m]:b∈{0,1}m∑​w^(f^​(b),b)=σ⎭⎬⎫​.

children.value: From the definition, we can see that CRS (constrained Reed-Solomon code) is first a RS code, i.e.,

children.html: f∈RS[F,L,m]f \in \mathrm{RS}[\mathbb{F}, \mathcal{L}, m]f∈RS[F,L,m]

children.value: in the definition, but on top of this, it needs to satisfy a summation constraint similar to Sumcheck

children.html: ∑b∈{0,1}mw^(f^(b),b)=σ\sum_{\mathbf{b} \in \{0,1\}^m} \hat{w}(\hat{f}(\mathbf{b}), \mathbf{b}) = \sigma∑b∈{0,1}m​w^(f^​(b),b)=σ

children.value: The paper [ACFY24b] mentions that the weight polynomial

children.html: w^\hat{w}w^

children.value: in the definition can be defined by oneself and has wide applications. The paper gives such an example: an evaluation constraint

children.html: f^(z)=σ\hat{f}(\mathbf{z}) = \sigmaf^​(z)=σ

children.value: , which constrains the value of the multivariate polynomial

children.html: f^\hat{f}f^​
z∈Fm\mathbf{z} \in \mathbb{F}^mz∈Fm

children.value: As mentioned earlier, BaseFold combined the Sumcheck and FRI protocols, while the WHIR protocol combines the ideas of BaseFold and STIR, replacing the FRI protocol in BaseFold with the STIR protocol. Compared to the FRI protocol, the STIR protocol has a smaller query complexity. The core idea of the STIR protocol is to reduce the rate of each iteration, increasing the redundancy in the messages sent by the Prover, thereby reducing the Verifier’s query complexity.

Let’s delve into one iteration of the WHIR protocol (from [ACFYb, 2.1.3 WHIR protocol]) to see how WHIR specifically combines BaseFold and the STIR protocol. After one iteration, the problem of testing the proximity of

children.value: After using sumcheck in step 1 of the protocol, the subsequent steps 2-5 are similar to the STIR protocol. The following figure shows one iteration of the STIR protocol.
The core idea of the STIR protocol is to reduce the rate in each iteration. Specifically, in the next iteration, the folded polynomial

children.html: g^\hat{g}g^​

children.value: . This corresponds to step 2 of the WHIR protocol. The benefit of doing this is that it greatly increases the redundancy of the sent messages, reducing the query complexity of the verifier.

children.value: The correlated agreement theorem given in the [BCIKS20] paper is a key theorem for proving the security of FRI and STIR protocols, which ensures that the process of folding the original function with random numbers in the FRI protocol or STIR protocol is secure. In the security analysis of WHIR, a new concept of mutual correlated agreement is introduced, which has a stronger conclusion than correlated agreement.
[ACFYb, 1.2 Mutual correlated agreement] gives the related definitions of correlated agreement and mutual correlated agreement. A code

children.value: . This also connects correlated agreement with mutual correlated agreement.

The WHIR protocol combines the ideas of BaseFold and STIR. First, for univariate polynomials in RS encoding, they can be viewed as equivalent multivariate linear polynomials through variable substitution, and the folding of univariate polynomials is also equivalent to folding the corresponding multivariate linear polynomials. This allows WHIR to support both univariate polynomials and multivariate linear polynomials.
Secondly, a new CRS encoding definition is given, adding a constraint similar to sumcheck on the basis of RS encoding, which is a constraint similar to sumcheck on the weight polynomial

children.html: w^\hat{w}w^

children.value: . The flexibility of the weight polynomial definition allows multiple constraints to be required at once in the protocol, including constraining the correctness of sumcheck, the correctness of out-of-domain answers, and the correctness of shift queries.

Then, by delving into one iteration of the WHIR protocol, we can see its connection with BaseFold and STIR protocols. The key here is still to build a bridge between univariate polynomials and multivariate linear polynomials, allowing free switching between the univariate function

children.html: fff
f^\hat{f}f^​

children.value: . Through the introduction of CRS, the goal of the protocol is increased to verify the correctness of a constraint similar to sumcheck,

children.value: . The subsequent steps of out-of-domain sample and shift queries in the WHIR protocol are similar to the STIR protocol.
Finally, we introduced the mutual correlated agreement conclusion used in the security proof of the WHIR protocol, which is stronger than the correlated agreement conclusion.
